titleStmt.title: Petition of the cap and hat makers of Bristol. 11 February, 1531

msIdentifier.msName: Petition of the cap and hat makers of Bristol

abstract.p: A petition to the King, dated 11 February 1531, was sent from Bristol to highlight the damage being done to the town and the wider realm by the selling of French caps and hats above the price mandated by statute 21 Henry VIII, c. 9 (1529). The act, intituled `an act limiting the prices of woollen hats, bonnets and caps made beyond the sea and brought to be sold within this realm', legislated that from the Purification of Our Lady (2 February, 1530), no person was to sell imported woollen caps and bonnets for more than two shillings, no hat above ten pence, and no night cap or crown cap above six pence. Any person selling above these prices would be fined forty shillings per item. Statutes of the Realm, III, p. 290. Eustace Chapuys, imperial ambassador to the court of Henry VIII, refers to the act in correspondence to the Emperor, claiming that the Duke of Norfolk brought the legislation to parliament. Calendar of State Papers, Spanish, Vol. 4, Part 1, 232. Stanford E. Lehmberg noted that Chapuys `complained' that the price of French caps were fixed even though they were of better quality. See Stanford E. Lehmberg in The Reformation Parliament 1529-1536 (London, 1970), p. 97, f. 3. However, Chapuys was framing the legislation in a positive light as an example of how Norfolk favoured Spanish and Flemish trade over French. An earlier act of 1512 (3 Henry VIII, c. 15) attempted to fix the price of domestically produced hats and limit the availability of imported hats to knights and nobility, with fines of forty shillings and the forefeiture of the hats to others. Statutes of the Realm, III, pp. 34-5l; see M. Hayward, Rich Apparel: Clothing and the Law in Henry VIII's England (Farnham, 2009), p. 26. The act of 1531 stated that the forefeiture would only extend to the sellers of foreign caps.

The petition from Bristol is one of eight similar petitions from towns involved in the cap and hat making trade held in the Parliamentary Archives at the Palace of Westminster. The petitions are from Shrewsbury, Bridgnorth, Bristol, Borough of Southwark, Gloucester, Bewdley, Stafford and Lichfield and have been calendared in the Third Report of the Royal Commission on Historical Manuscripts (London, 1872), p. 4. The petition from the Borough of Southwark is discussed in H. Duckworth, `The Early History of Feltmaking in London 1250-1604' (June, 2013) [http://www.feltmakers.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Feltmakers-Research-Paper-Final-version.pdf] The Bristol petition states that if the act was better observed then it would benefit the town of Bristol since 1500 poor men, women and children derive most of their living from the production of hats.

p.hi:
To the kyng owre sovereign lorde
and to his most honorable Counsaill

div.p:
Pleaseth it yor your highnes and your moost noble counsaill to have perfite knowledge what damages doth ensue to yor your said
highnes and to the Subgectes of this yor your Realme by reason of bryngyng of ffrenssh cappes and hattes owte of dyverse parties from
beyonde the See which is to the utter destruction of all yor your power Subgectes cappe makers and hatte makers inhabited wtin within
yor your Towne of Bristowe

Where of late yor your highnes by the advise of yor your lordes spirituall and temporall and Comyns assembled in yor your high courte of Parliament
last holden at Westminster establisshed and inacted for the comon Welth of yor your poore Subgectes cappe makers and hatte makers, that no cappe made
owte of yor your Realme shulde be solde above the price of ij s nor any hatte above the price of x d nor any sengle crowned Cappe or nyght
cappe above the price of vj d And that upon payne that every person mysusyng the said Statute shulde forfaite for every cappe or hatte solde
above the said price xl s Which acte if it were duely observed and kept were to the greate weale and profite of us yor your poore Subgectes being
Inhabited wtin within
yor your saide Towne of Bristowe, which is occupied in greate part therof by makyng of cappes and hattes to the Nombre of xv c
persons poore people men, wemen and Children which geteth theire moost lyvyng oonly by making of the said cappes and hattes as Parters
fforcers, kembers, carders, Spynners, knytters, Thickers, dressers, dyers and pressers of cappes. And noo Cappe can be made, but he must goo thuegh
the handes of thise poore people. And they all have theire levyng by the same to the greate Releef and comforte of yor your saide Subgectes. And myght be
moche more profitable And many moo ydull people setto werke wtin within this yor your saide Towne if the saide Acte were duely observed and kepte. Where as
nowe by dyvers chapmen commyng fro London Towne into the countrey to ffeyers and merkettes for singuler welthe and profite of very fewe persons to
the Nombre of us yor your poore Subgectes doth sell ffrenshe cappes and hattes disguysed wt with rebandes, Aglettes, buttons and suche other like. Whereby all suche
cappes and hattes made by us yor your poore Subgectes of Bristowe and other Townes theraboute byn litle regarded. And have no course. In consideration
wherof it may in the way of charitie pleas yor your highnes (tenderly consideryng the greate utilite and profite that by consernyng the said Statute to be kepte
in due Ordre may ensue to yor your
Subgectes of this yor your poore Towne. And the greate enormytie and fynall destruction that myght folowe to A greate Nombre of
yor your poore Subgectes by the mysusyng of the said Statute of yor your moost habundaunt grace to prove suche condigne punysshement to be used and doon to the
said misusers, as may be to the ensample of such other offenders. And as the said Statute may be from hensforth firmely observed and kepte. And thenne
suche ydull people which nowe for lak of occupation fallen dailly to Thefte and other Inconveniences may be sette to werke. And this yor your poore Towne to
be moche better inhabited and replenysshed which nowe decaith Wherefor we in moost humble wise mekely beseke yor your moost excellent highnes to tendre
this yor your said Towne of Bristowe in the premisses. And we shall dailly pray to god for yor your moost noble estate in riall felicite to prospere and endure. And for
the more surety that the premisses be of truth. the Seale of thoffice of the Mairaltie of yor your said Towne of Bristowe for the comon weale of the same
to thise presents putte. Yoven at yor your said Towne of Bristowe the xj th day of ffebruary. In the xxijth of yor your moost noble reign
